Constructor Detail

Game

public Game()
Game class constructor assumes you're playing against AI. (Use the Game(boolean) constructor if you want to set up network game)

Game

public Game(boolean networkTF)
Game class constructor When running tests, I don't want the JOptionPane to put up dialog boxes that require mouse click to dismiss. The testing boolean is final, so can only be set at startup!

Game

public Game(boolean networkTF,
            boolean newTesting)
Game class constructor Sets title bar, size, shows the window, and does the GUI

Connection with an instance of Game successfully established. Start the game. "The client initiating the connection decides who goes first."

doCancel

public void doCancel(Board aBoard,
                     Player playerColor)
Cancelling a choice of point, saying "I don't really want to move from here after all"

doRoll

public void doRoll(Board aBoard,
                   Player playerColor)
Roll the dice for the current player. If current player is on the bar then this calls "aBoard.selectABar( )" If the current player can't move, this calls "Game.forfeitTurn( )" This is stronger than merely telling a board's dice to roll, which doesn't check for bar nor canMove [ ]This is smarter than Board.roll. Should Board.roll( ) get its brains?

drawBearStats

public void drawBearStats(Board aBoard)
Announce how many pieces each player beared off so far

public void drawBoardScore(Board aBoard)
Currently turned off since score comes from one of the strategies now rather than directly from the board

public void drawCurrentPlayer(Board aBoard)
Puts their name on board ("white" "black" "game_unstarted")

drawPipStats

public void drawPipStats(Board aBoard)

endPartialMove

public void endPartialMove(Player playerColor)
This is for Partial Move Remove focus from a certain point which has been selected This allows the player to select a new point. called by Board, so can't be private. Disables the CancelChoice button because there's not a tentative partial move to cancel anymore!

endTurn

public void endTurn(Board aBoard,
                    Player playerColor,
                    String additionalMessage)
End the current player's turn and start the turn of the other player. Perhaps redundant that "currentPlayer" is specified ... Is called by Board, so it can't be private. Calls startTurn( ), which sets "fButton[btn_RollDice].setEnabled(true);"

findX

public int findX(int point)
Gets the X coordinate of the (center of?) the specified point (aka "column" or "spike"), for displaying blots and the "move here" buttons which will be shown just below the point of possible destinations.

findY

public int findY(int point)
Gets the Y coordinate (??) of the bottom of the triangle of the specified point (aka "column" or "spike"), for displaying blots and "move here" buttons which will be just below the point of possible destinations.

forfeitTurn

public void forfeitTurn(Board aBoard,
                        Player playerColor)
Forfeit the current player's turn. Is called by Board, so can't be private.

getCurrentPlayer

public Player getCurrentPlayer()
returns (point to) currentPlayer or null means game unstarted formerly returned int white = 1; black = 2; (shouldn't ever have neutral = 0;)

getMyBoard

public Board getMyBoard()
Returns the game's mainboard, which (currently) is the only board with gui display (View) and gui buttons (Controller). Other boards are created to test hypothetical moves but don't have V & C and any moves upon those hypothetical boards are not official moves of the game. [ ]Games ought to keep a history of official moves!

getPointNum

public int getPointNum(int point_x,
                       int point_y)
This seems to figure out which point on display board is touched by the x,y int coordinates. Might be bar, and in that case I have to know who the current player is.

hidePartialMoves

public void hidePartialMoves()
would be nice to have a specific hidePartialMove(x) method, especially for doing undo...

paint

public void paint(Graphics g)
Talking to "mainBoard" which is the public display (MVC) of the most visible board, but isn't necessarily the temp board that is trying out temporary moves when the AI is playing with itself.

paintPartialMoveButtons

receiveBar

public void receiveBar(Board aBoard,
                       int point)
The local (non-network) player got sent to the bar, so update the board. Apparently point is a number from the point of view of the opponent? Apparently remote network player is always black on our screen, while perhaps white on her screen?? So that's why we're doing the 25 - point thing??

receiveMove

public void receiveMove(Board aBoard,
                        Player playerColor,
                        int oldpos,
                        int newpos,
                        int rollValue)
The network player has moved, update the board. Apparently remote network player is always black on our screen, while perhaps white on her screen?? (which explains why her moves are getting (25 - X)). Apparently oldpos value -1 used to mean coming in from bar, and 26 meant bearing off? Are the constants being handed in properly for BAR_ and BEAR? Probably not. This isn't using any of the improved selectAPoint and moveBlot code yet.

Specified by:
receiveMove in interface CommunicationAdapter

showPartialMove

public void showPartialMove(PartialMove p,
                            Player playerColor,
                            int moveNum)
Puts visible buttons on start and end of the move. Should it do them in the order of dice and potMove, or in the order of actually being done <--probably better. (Counting 0,1,2 but named 1,2,3...).

Parameters:
moveNum - either explicit 1,2,3,4 OR 0 means use lowest invisible buttons. I.E. caller doesn't know which move this is and wants us to figure it out.

turnFinished

public void turnFinished(Board aBoard)
The network player has finished his turn. Start the local player's turn Is "local" always white, or randomly decided in connected( )??

Specified by:
turnFinished in interface CommunicationAdapter
